Award.AwardTitle: Probing Highly Non-equilibrium Thermal Transport in Nanostructures and Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1336968
PI: Li Shi (U Texas, Austin)

Different electron and phonon populations can be driven out of local thermal equilibrium in nanoelectronic devices, laser materials processing, and thermal transport measurements. A better understanding of the highly non-equilibrium transport phenomena is necessary for the design of next-generation devices and material structures with enhanced performance and reliability. However, current experimental capabilities are inadequate for probing local temperatures of these different energy excitations. Despite the recent progresses in scanning thermal microscopy (SThM), infrared spectroscopy, and micro-Raman spectroscopy, there is a lack of experimental methods for resolving the local temperature of the acoustic phonons that dominate heat conduction, as well as low-frequency acoustic phonons that may be in the ballistic transport regime in nanostructures. The objective of this research is to investigate new experimental methods for probing the local temperature of acoustic phonons during highly non-equilibrium transport processes in nanostructures and devices. The techniques to be investigated include a new method based on micro-Brillouin light scattering (BLS) for probing the local temperature of low-frequency (0.5 GHz to 100?s GHz) acoustic phonons with sub-micron spatial resolution. Based on preliminary BLS measurements of local acoustic phonon temperatures in glass, this technique will be investigated further for probing the local acoustic phonon temperature in silicon nanostructures that are either electrically biased or optically excited. The obtained acoustic phonon temperature will be correlated with those measured by micro-Raman spectroscopy, infrared spectroscopy, and SThM to quantify local non-equilibrium between electrons, acoustic and optical phonons.

The demonstration of the micro-BLS technique as a thermal microscopy tool for low-frequency phonons will be of value for the experimental thermal transport research community. Meanwhile, the measurement data can be used by theoretical and computational thermal transport researchers to establish a better understanding of several intriguing and important non-equilibrium transport phenomena. Such understanding can impact further advances in nanoelectronic devices, laser materials processing, and thermal measurement techniques. In addition, this research will provide student training opportunities in state-of-the-art experimental techniques, and result in new example materials for undergraduate and graduate courses. It will also generate new demonstration materials to be used in outreach activities for attracting students from underrepresented groups to engineering and science professions, and for exposing university research to K-12 students, parents, and teachers in Texas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronic devices such as computers and smart phones are continually improving to keep pace with consumer demand. From an engineering design perspective, one of the most prevalent ways to improve devices is by making the components smaller in order to pack more computing power into a smaller package. However, with the increased power density comes a cost: increased heating density. In modern electronic devices that are getting smaller and faster, the heating is occurring over smaller length scales and shorter time scales. When the heating occurs over time and length scales that become very short, the traditional way that we analyze heat flow, using Fourier’s law, becomes inadequate. Since the heat must be conducted away in order to prevent overheating and device failure, it is important to understand how thermal energy is transported over these short time and length scales to allow for continued advancement in micro- and nanoelectronics.


Inside materials, thermal energy is transferred from one region to another by microscopic quanta of energy, including electrons, phonons, and magnons, the latter two of which are energy quanta of atomic vibration waves and magnetic fluctuation. In very small devices, these energy carriers can be heated to different temperatures. When such thermal non-equilibrium exists among the different energy carriers, the Fourier description of heat transport, which says the temperature gradient that arises is directly proportional to the applied heat flux via the material’s thermal conductivity, is not accurate. 


In this project, unique experimental methods have been established to help answer the following important question: how significant is this thermal non-equilibrium inside materials that are used in modern and emerging electronic devices? Experiments have been conducted on silicon that has been used in practically every electronic device for the past 50 years, some magnetic materials that may play an important role in upcoming computer memories and energy conversion devices, and graphene and other two dimensional (2D) materials that are of interest for flexible electronic devices. Often times, when one is interested in studying energy carrier transport in materials, one must place a probe in physical contact with the system of interest. However, the physical contact can interfere with the measurement by introducing contact resistances, uncertainties, or heat loss through the probe. Instead, optical non-contact measurements have been established in this research to probe the temperatures and transport of different energy carriers. Additionally, focused laser heating has been employed to generate local thermal non-equilibrium between different energy carriers and determine the length scales for them to achieve thermal equilibrium between each other.  


The advances made here in the experimental capabilities have enabled several discoveries. It has been found that phonons and magnons can be driven out of local equilibrium by localized heating over a length scale of about 2 to 4 µm in the magnetic insulator yttrium iron garnet (YIG), and that different vibrational modes in graphene are similarly out of equilibrium over around a 1 µm scale. Given that modern devices routinely contain components that are about 1,000 times smaller than these µm length scales, the effects of non-equilibrium thermal transport can be very significant. Furthermore, to help model the heat dissipation when non-equilibrium is present, a multi-temperature model that contains information on the temperatures of all the different energy carriers have been established. The experimental discoveries made in this project should help to enable the continued advancement of micro- and nanoelectronic devices. 


Four graduate students and one undergraduate student have participated in this research and received training in optical measurements and theoretical modeling of thermal energy transport. Two of the graduate students have completed a PhD degree, including a female PhD who has continued scientific research at MIT Lincoln Laboratory after graduation. The undergraduate student completed a BS degree and is now a graduate student at CalTech. In addition, the research team has built an optical measurement module for demonstration in a campus-wide outreach event, so as to introduce thermal science and engineering to K-12 students.
